snippet: From interregional sharing to the development of batteries, Energy Secretary Steven Chu offers ideas for coping with a sudden oversupply of power to the grid.
abstract: From interregional sharing to the development of batteries, Energy Secretary Steven Chu offers ideas for coping with a sudden oversupply of power to the grid.
lead_paragraph: Last year I wrote about sudden surges in renewable energy that set up a conflict between wind producers in the Pacific Northwest and the Bonneville Power Administration, a federal agency that runs hydroelectric dams and the regional grid. When unseasonable storms created a simultaneous surplus of wind and water, Bonneville gave free power away but still had to deal with an oversupply that could overwhelm the grid.
